results.notes:
I found two examples of this species today, one small (~3" cap diameter), and another much larger (~5" cap diameter and quite heavy!). Both were growing independently, but about 200 yards away from one another. Neither veil had released from the cap yet, so gills were not visible yet. Looking under the cap, young gills are large and white. Stalks are very thick and dense, with multiple rings running around the circumference. As seen in photos, scales are rather pronounced. No yellowing upon cutting or bruising.

They were located about 1/2 mile from the ocean in a dense Cambria/Monterey Pine understory, not in a grassland area as they said to normally be found. Other mixed conifers and shrubs were also present.

Smell is pleasant, quite almondy, and the flesh is thick and firm. The cooked flavor of the mushroom is mild and sweet, and quite fragrantly almond-like, with a chewy, snappy texture. The fragrance/flavor of the mushroom persists for some time. There was a very faint bitterness, but not at all unpleasant.

results.notes:
Thallus is a few millimeters across, mineral gray, with what appear to be black apothecia lacking margins. White rhizines apparent beneath. It appears to be growing on top of Punctelia rudecta on a fallen twig. Northern forest, red spruce, northern white cedar, red maple. Extremely rich lichen habitat!

I thought of the possibility that these were lobes of the P. rudecta, discolored by the infection, and that the apothecia belonged to the infection. However, they really do appear to be independent of and on top of the P rudecta. Very small, sterile gray thalli also seen on top of P. rudecta lobes.

Photographs were taken in the studio in October. Collection was in August.
Grateful for any suggestions.

results.notes:
This and observation 221291 are related to observation 261167 and come in the sequel of the comments made by Fredo therein concerning the possible ID for the species there considered. I knew that I had observed before at the same place the species under consideration.
In observation 221291 I thought erroneously that the species was Volvopluteus gloiocephalus, ignoring the dimensions of the specimens, the grey silky-fibrilose pileus with fimbriate margin and the yelow tones noticiable at the bottom of the stipe (that separated from the volva). Curiously, Volvopluteus gloiocephalus also exists at that place (see observation 221290 from that same day).
At the same day and some 50-70 meters from that place I saw it again and uploaded the corresponging photos to this observation.

results.notes:
An unusual Cortinarius we found in a patch of old (nearing the peak of successsion) mixed taiga forest (Pinus sibirica, Picea obovata, Populus tremula, Pinus sylvestris, Abies sibirica, Betula pendula). It’s almost fluorescently bright with its orange glow, recalling a Dermocybe, but otherwise almost leprocybeoid. C. cinnabarinus and C. bulliardii come to mind, but those are both nemoral broadleaf forest species and look different.
I’m wondering if anybody has seen anything similar in boreal latitudes.

results.notes:
Updated with photos from another flush — had plenty of rain the past two weeks and now a couple of days of 60deg and partial sunshine. Then an eruption of mushrooms!

Found three flushes growing in the garden soil, in our raised bed gardens. First flush about a month ago, then one a couple of weeks ago, and a third today. Garden beds were amended last spring with composted chicken and steer manure. We grow shiitake and enokitake mushrooms on inoculated logs nearby. No kitchen compost was used in the garden beds.

Weather, had two hard frosts the past month. Temperatures in the 40-50 daytime with lows in the 30s overnight. Plenty of precipitation the past month. With no rain the past 3 days.

Gills are pinkish brown on the younger specimen, turning darker brown on the older specimens.
No rings on the stem.
White flesh turns pinkish brown after being cut (about an hour later or do).
Texture is firm, gives when pressed.
Caps range in color from white to light brown. Are dry to the touch, some have fine slight scaling as they age.
Smells delightfully mushroomy, earthy. Smells like portabella mushroom, actually.

Pulled a young button and have added photos below. White veil still attached, short stem bulbous toward the bottom. But this one was mostly still under the soil and feels damp, slippery. When cut longitudinally is was white with brownish inside, damp and spongy, very much like a grocery store mushroom that’s been sitting on the shelf too long. Smells also like a spoiled grocery mushroom.

Spore print shows abundant spores of chocolate brown color. Looks like cocoa powder. See photos below.

See photos for location and features.
Waiting on spore test. Will add photos.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1031/2017_DSC6723

Habitat: alpine forest, Picea abies, Fagus sylvatica, Larix decidua dominant trees, almost flat terrain, calcareous ground, in shade, partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 8-10 deg C,
elevation 1.660 m (5.450 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: Dead branch of Larix decidua.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, above Na Skali settlement, next to the trail from Planina V Plazeh to Mt. Čisti vrh, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comment: Thallus pendant, approximately 30 cm long, completely dry (after more than one month of dry weather, temperatures below 0 deg C); many lichens present.
The species was once abundant in mountain forests. However, it is very sensitive to air pollution and is hence in strong decline in many places in Europe where it is considered endangered and (mostly) protected. Plants with apothecia became rare. At higher elevations in Trenta valley this lichen is still quite common and apothecia are still abundant. However, even here some damages due to pollution can be observed (brown dots on apothecia surface – see arrows on Fig. 11).This lichen has been historically used to treat wounds and modern tests for antibacterial properties have been positive. The lichen contains antibiotic usnin-acid, which is nowadays synthetically produced.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8/

Place: Lower Trenta valley, settlement Lemovlje, above the trail from the settlement to TV repeater, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

results.notes:
Observado en Cerro El Venado, altura entre 500 – 600 msnm; bosque húmedo pre montano (bh-PM), precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio, con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante, et al 2013). Yopal cuenta con una extensión de 2595 km, Altura media: 390 msnm y una Población Total de 146 204 hab. (2005)

-Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%), pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, (DANE, 1999; Castro & Sosa, 2017)

-Se observan arboles representativos como Yarumo (Cecropia spp), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
results.location_name: Yopal, Casanare, Colombia

results.notes: Visto en el Humedal la Conejera creciendo sobre madera en 4º 45´ latitud norte y 74º 6´ longitud oeste en la Sabana de Bogotá, altura promedio de 2542 msnm. Encontrado en ecosistema de humedal (Humedal La Conejera) bosque de Salix humboldtiana y Alnus acuminata. Humedad relativa del 80% (Chisacá, 2002) y una temperatura mínima que varían entre 0.9°C y – 4.2°C y promedio de 18-19°C (FHLC, 2002).
results.location_name: Bogotá, Colombia

results.notes: After extremely hot heat wave conditions for weeks, and no real rain in this forest region for over 2 years, we had a Storm Cell form on the Mountain that delivered 52mm (2") of overnite rain. The location of the fungi is in a low section of the Eucalyptus coastal rainforest. Single fruiting body only at the edge of the forest treeline about 5 meters off the dirt track. I think this specimen may be the same as the partially dried Obs; 264311. This current fungi is a fine specimen. Small Warts visible covering the cap. Well define bulb. As sunrise was forming image daylight rays of sunlight required some small temp adjustments, (PS), to some images. These have been made to show detail where some small areas of burn out occurred from sunlight rays during image collection.

results.notes: Small ball shaped white single fruiting body above forest soil but covered with light debris. Masses of fine hair roots attached to main body. When specimen bisected lookes similar to MO Obs: 237192. There was no hard casing enveloping the fungi, and it was easly cut showing a meaty inner area. Two sections were separated by colour of the inner texture, and a gelatine like substance surrounded the inner body. There was no juice or excrement released when cut. Specimen has been dried and is available for posting if so wished..

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1026/2016_DSC6356

Habitat: mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies dominant trees; moderately inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; skeletal, colluvial, calcareous ground; in shade; relatively warm and dry place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 560 m (1.840 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: on somewhat over-mature Rhizopogon aestivus fruitbody.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, near Skokar farm house, Trenta 2, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Orange blobs on the surface of almost black sporocarp of Rhizopogon aestivus are anamorph form of a parasitic fungus Clonostachys rosea (teleomorph formerly known as Bionectria). This was determined by growing fungus in culture from herbarium sample (Ref.:1). Clonostachys rosea is a common species found on several substrates including other fungi (fungicolous species). It colonizes living plants as an endophyte, can live in ground living as a saprophyte, or lives as a parasite on other fungi or nematodes. It produces several kinds of mycotoxins. It is used in biological pest control on vegetable, mostly for treatment of grey mold (Botrytis cinerea) of tomato and strawberries.

The long fusiform and septated conidia also observed belong most probably to another fungus belonging to genus Fusarium. It has not been determined to species level.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
This day the field trip had a clear target: Rinodina, again. Particularly, I had in mind to understood if the specimens found in my previous observation 259572 and observation 238585, concerning R. oxydata and R. capensis, respectively, were product of chance or if the places where they were found have noticeable populations of those species. For me it was a great success, since I was able to find plenty of specimens for each of those species, as I will show in observations to come. Naturally, such target field trips always give also some subproducts. One of these was already considered, starting from observation 267462 to observation 267468 were a number of different Cladonia spp. were reported. Another was a number of samples of Buellia, certainly of more than one species, being difficult to say how many without further study. But within Rinodina I suppose to have encountered again the species R. sophodes, particularly difficult to find due to the reduced size of thalli (see observation 241353). This is the subject of the present observation.
Rinodina oxydata will be considered at observation 267580 and R. capensis at observation 267581. There are also some other Rinodina for which I have samples and that can be other species, but the microscopy will be needed to be certain. Clearly microscopy will be also needed to substantiate my comments above, but I’m very confident about the species mentioned.
results.location_name: Serra de São Mamede, Portugal

results.notes:
Notes: See the notes of observation 267579.

This observation is devoted to a species of Rinodina. Taking into account the results obtained in my first encountered with it (see observation 259572) must belong to a restrict group of species: R. fimbriata, R. oxidata, R. teichophila. My impression at the time was that there was a good probability of being R. oxidata. Now, based on the first results obtained from microscopy, I’m not so sure about that
(… to be developed in the comments).

I must make a note about the habitat where all the specimens considered here were found (see the photo with the habitat). It consist of an old fence, visually infinite, but the courious fact is that I only found specimens in the first part of it, say in 30-40 meters. Outside that part, none. I looked for any difference in the rocks of the fence, but seems homogeneous. Then, what is the reason?
results.location_name: Serra de São Mamede, Portugal

results.notes:
See the notes of observation 267579.
This observation is devoted to Rinodina capensis. As mentioned in my first observation of this species, its grow form is such that it can be spreaded by the group of trees (maybe a dozen, mainly Quercus suber) in a great number of minuscule thalli, sometimes consisting of a few number of apothecia (say 3 or 4, as for example in the photo labeled as Sp. 1) and others with a, say regular thallus, of about 2 cm across and crowed of apothecia (photos with specimens 2 to 4 already uploaded). I got a numerous set of samples from this field trip, which include the specimens mentioned above and collected also some small branches of the trees with numerous specimens for future study.
I already started with the microscopy and it seems that this is species I thought to be. Soon I will upload some photos with the main results.

results.notes:
Same collection location as observation 265024.

Location is upper Morro Creek along Highway 41 West, between Morro Bay and Atascadero.
Habitat is riparian, with a dense canopy of live oak, California bay, sycamore and willow. The specific location is a deep shaded canyon.
Substrate is hard siliceous boulder situated at or just above the high flood line of the creek. Probably does not become inundated.

Thallus is crustose, thin, whitish grey, developing into brown fertile areoles. Thallus cortex K-. Photobiont is trentopohlioid, as determined by orange pigments. Apothecia semi-immersed, with slightly raised thalline margin and whitish to rarely pinkish disk. Spent apothecia leave a crater. Hymenium and hypothecium hyaline, Hymenium IKI+blue, epihymenium hyaline, both K-, epipsamma seems absent. Paraphyses adglutinated, not moniliform.

Ascus narrowly clavate, 8-spored, uniserate, tholus IKI-? Spores hyaline, simple, ellipsoid. Measurements:
11.5×4.2µm
14.0×4.3µm
12.7×4.9µm

Discussion: Spore size fits Ionaspis alba, a little on the narrow side. I thought it might be Hymenelia because of slightly pinkish apothecia disks, but spores do not fit any of the species. I’d bet this is common in specific micro-habitat areas but is just overlooked. My first collection was entirely by accident, I didn’t even see it on the rock until I got home.

results.notes:
Description:

Pileus: 11-36 × 4-7 mm; convex to plane with low and fairly flat umbo; slightly sulcate margin; pruinose when young, somewhat remaining pruinose in the centre; finely granular surface (20x magn.) probably caused by sphaerical endcells in the pileipellis, dry to slightly tacky; starting off plum coloured, gradually showing more red around the margin, dark blackish purple in centre; cuticle peels to 1/3-1/2, reddish tones underneath the cuticle.

Lamellae: L: 56-75, l: 0-1; horizontally adnate, margins very finely fimbriate; subdistant; very little colour of the pileus spilling over at the margin of the pileus; very few lamellulae; white.

Spore print: White.

Stipe: 23-45 × 3-9 mm; cilindrical to subclavate, centrally attached; dry, surface finely but clearly rugulose over entire length; white with over time (after picking) slightly reddish brown base; very lightly attached to the ground.

Context: Firm, brittle, solid throughout; white, ever so slightly reddish in outmost base, cortex clearly visible directly after cross-section, but gradually fading over time.

Smell/taste: No particular scent; very actrid after a short amount of sourness.

Chem. ana.: Quick and fairly strong pinkish-orangy reaction to FeSO4, after 15 minutes reaction runs over large section of stipe around initial bruise; slight greenish after KOH 3% on context of stipe.

Microscopy:

- Spores: (Sub)globose to broadly ellipsoid; warts and small ridges forming a near to complete reticulum, which can be thin to fairly thick; warts are low (<0,5 µm).

- Measurements (1000x; H2O + Melzer; oil-im.; 1 sd = 1,02 µm; n=9)

- 8,16 × 5,10 µm
- 8,16 × 6,12 µm
- 7,14 × 6,12 µm

- 6,12 × 5,10 µm
- 8,16 × 6,12 µm
- 7,14 × 6,12 µm

results.notes:
This is a common kind in this location and it is far away from aspen, sometimes between pine and birch, usually nearby pine-trees. It was studied when abundant (bruising and age discolouring – lots of photos). (Local name: Красноголовик сосновый, «Подосиновик»)
Cap: 6-18cm convex up to broadly convex; surface fine velvety as old skin, minor smooth in wet weather; orange-red and orange (young), pale brownish-orange or pale red-orange (adult) up to dull orange-yellow or brownish-yellow and sometimes with a net of cracks (old and drying up). Age discolouring is common, especially with sun light, so there are red spots and strips under branches and leaves. Odour is weak and pleasant. Flesh is white and the older the softer and darker; after damage it bruising pink or light red (young), purplish-pink (adult), purplish-grey or grey (old and drying up); the drier weather, the slower bruising.
Tubes: attached (sometimes almost free when very old, cause a ring depression under a cap around stalk), colour from whitish up to brownish-white or very light dull brown, sometimes with irregular dull reddish-brown spots (old).
Stalk: 6-16cm long, 1.5-3cm thick and enlarged down; whitish with tiny projections, projections colour is pinkish-white then brownish-gray or gray; bruising pink or light red (young), purplish-pink (adult), purplish-grey or grey (old); sometimes the cutting of an old base is light greenish-blue.
Habitat: small group nearby pine-trees or their stumps.
Edibility: tasty.
Season: June – August.
results.location_name: Borovoye National Park, Akmola District, Kazakhstan

Substrate: On roots.

Habit: Grouped, multiple individuals growing inches apart, not from a common base.

Pileus 0.3cm-2.2cm, laterally stipitate, fan-shaped, surface smooth, dry and soft, tough (leathery), even margin, white when immature, chestnut brown to yellow brown, with brown bands and creamy to pale yellow edge on upper surface at maturity, turns darker chestnut brown and edge becomes dark brown with white splotches with age. Veil
Veil and veil remnants are absent

results.notes:
This is similar to 50992 and 74093 (?).
Cap: 10-20cm wide, convex when young up to almost flattened with indistinct depressed centre; light brown up to chocolate brown usually with white cracks that make an image of appressed scales in age, smooth when young; margin often inrolled. Flesh has very weak pinkish-brown bruising.
Stalk: 6-10cm long, brownish-white up to light brown.
Spines: decurrent, 5-10 mm, light brown (sometimes violet brown) up to brown with whitish tips.
Habitat: common kind, small group minor single in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
Edibility: purplish after boiling, fried mushroom has good, but specific taste as somewhat smoked meat; taste of dried fresh mushroom is intensely bitter.
Season: July-September.

results.notes:
Habitat: mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica and Picea abies dominant, moderately southeast inclined mountain slope, shallow, skeletal calcareous ground, old overgrown slope and moraine scree with larger rocks and boulders, in shade, relatively warm place, partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies, average precipitation ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7 – 9 deg C, elevation 600 m (1.970 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: debarked roots of dead Picea abies, still standing.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, next to the trail from Trenta 2b cottage to abandoned farmhouse ‘Strgulc’, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Fuligo septica is probably the most common and widely known Myxomicete. One of its varieties – Fuligo septica var. flava – has vivid yellow aethalia and yellow plasmodium (I haven’t seen it this time). Yet, this typical color pertains only to mature but still fresh aethalia (pictures 10-13). With time cortex becomes darker, almost golden (picture 14), then black inside becomes visible (pictures 15, 16). In next phase cortex become whitish (pictures 17, 18) and finally it disappears and only blackish-reddish-brown spore mass is seen (pictures 19, 20). It is interesting that this find was found only a few meters away of the site where I photographed the same species two years ago (see Album Fuligo septica var. flava – I, Dec. 2014) (see MO observations #194527). In both observations spores are unusually large.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

results.notes:
On a wood fence along the RXR tracks

Thallus whitish grey, scant, K-, C- with numerous dispersed black convex biatorine apothecia. Hymenium hyaline, hypothecium hyaline, epihymenium blueish black, K-.

Asci broadly clavate and appear to have many ascospores. I didn’t get any I+ blue in the tholus, but I might have screwed up the test. Strangospora moriformis has a blue epihymenium and 100-200 ascospores per ascus. Maybe the asci are so immature that it just looks like many ascospores but is realy 8, and the epihymenium is aeruginose like Lecidea?
